I came down stairs before the prisoner, at twenty minutes past six o'clock—I went to the till, and there were then two 3d.-pieces, four 4d.-pieces, and 2s. worth of copper—it was not locked—I went up stairs for about two minutes to get the key, and then went to the till to lock it—no other person had come down—I missed a 3d.-piece—I called my wife down—she counted the copper in my presence, and there was 7d. missing—I spoke to the prisoner about it—she denied it, and said if I wanted to make her a thief I might, but she was not—I said I had detected her before, and could not be robbed any longer—she said she did not care how many policemen I fetched, she was no thief.

CHARLES ROWBERRY (policeman, K 347). I was sent for to the prose
cutor's—the prisoner was not there—I afterwards met her with Mrs. Atkin, who in her presence gave me a 3d.-piece, three pence, and five halfpence, which she said she had just brought from Mrs. Gilson's—I took the prisoner—on the way to the station, she said she took the money to Mrs. Gilson's just after dinner.
NOT GUILTY .

2188.
WILLIAM ARMITAGE
, burglariously breaking and entering the dwelling-house of
John Fenton, and stealing therein 2 coats, I shawl, and 1 pair of boots, value 2l., his goods; and
ANDREW POWELL
, feloniously receiving the same.

JOHN FENTON . I am a linendraper and smack-owner, of Barking—Armitage was my apprentice. On 23rd Aug. I fastened up my house, and went to bed—the prisoner did not sleep in the house that night; he had absconded a fortnight before—I came down next morning, and found the kitchen window-shutter taken down—I missed three coats, two pairs of trowsers, and other articles—on 14th Sept. Armitage was found in a cupboard in the kitchen, covered over with pieces of wood—I gave him in charge—some property was shown me by the police, which was mine—I went with them to Rosemary-lane—Powell was sitting at a door there—Armitage said, "That is the man I sold the things to"—the policeman searched Powells house, produced two great coats, a pair of trowsers, and a shawl, which are mine, and these boots also.

Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Armitage was an apprentice to a Barking smack? A. Yes; for three or four months—he went several voy
ages before he was bound, and, I think, two since, and then he ran away—I cannot tell what time he got into the house that night—I have had these cow six months—(putting one on)—this one fits me—they were lying across Powell's counter—the shawl was concealed in a box—the police took seme silk away, which I found was not mine.

BENJAMIN TBAWN (policeman). On 14th Sept. I was called in to Mr. Fenton's, and found Armitage secreted under a dresser, with pieces of wood covered over his breast—he said he had committed the robbery, and had got through the hole in the former part of the night—there was a hole in the ceil
ing in the back house—I went with him next day to Powell's, in Rosemary—lane—he was in his shop—Armitage said, in his hearing, "He is the man that bought the articles"—I searched, and found three coats.

HENRY BARNES (policeman, K 256). I went to Powell's on 15th—directly we got in Armitage said, "That is the man I sold the articles to, which I stole from Mr. Fenton"—I asked Powell to allow me to see them—he said, "I never bought any coats"—I said, "Then allow me to see the slops; is that one laying on the counter?"—he said, "Yes; I did buy a slop"—I took him, searched, and found another slop—I put my hand on a box—he said, "Those are my wife's clothes"—the wife said, "Those are all my clothes"—I found this shawl in a blanket, in the box—Mr. Fenton claimed it.

Cross-examined. Q. What did you ask him? A. I said, "Let me see tie slops you bought of him"—he said, "I bought two of him," and pulled a yarn frock from the window-board—I said, "Let me see the other"—he said, "I bought no more of him"—I did not search any other shops in Petticoat-lane.
GEORGE BEST (policeman, K 333). On 15th Sept. I found these women's boots, wrapped up with some linen in a box, at Powell's—I had asked him what the box contained—he said, his wife's linen.
MART ANN FENTON . I know this shawl—I have had it three years—I wore it on the Sunday before it was taken.

p.rs: GUILTY of Larceny. Aged 16.—Recommended to mercy.

div1.p:
POWELL—
GUILTY . Aged 44.—Each
confined Twelve Months.

2189.
REDMOND GEARY
, assaulting
Bridget Winiford Artnell, with intent, &c.

GUILTY of an Assault. Aged 41.—
Confined Nine Months.

2190.
SARAH HICKLEY,
WILLIAM HICKLEY , and
JOHN HICK
LEY
, stealing 1s.; the moneys of
Edward Winch.

JOHN CARPENTER (policeman, R 84). On 9th Sept., between six and eight at night, I was at Deptford-bridge, watching the prisoners—Sarah went into a great many shops, the others waited outside, sometimes twenty and sometimes thirty yards off—she went to Mr. Winch, Trafalgar-row—I saw a bottle of ginger-beer put on the counter—she laid down a shilling—the land
lady took away the ginger-beer, and she took up the shilling—they had some conversation—Mrs. Winch put up a glass of ale, which she drank—Mrs. Winch gave her some money from the till, and she left—I inquired, came out, and followed the prisoners to another public-bouse, and then to the railway, where I took them—I told them they were charged with obtaining money at various shops by false pretences—they said they did not knowwhat I meant—I re
peated it—Sarah said, "The shopkeeper was a great fool if she did not get the shilling"—I searched John and found a number of aricles.
Cross-examined by MR. ROBINSON. Q. Was it dark? A. It was just dusk—I looked in at the door—I was in plain clothes—the others were thirty yards from me—it was not fifty.

MART WINCH . I am the wife of Edward Winch, who keeps a beer-shop at Trafalgar-row, Greenwich. On 9th Sept. the female prisoner came and asked for a bottle of ginger-beer—I served her—she laid down a shilling and asked if I had a fourpenny-piece—I said I had not, and gave sixpence and fourpence—she said she wanted penny beer—I said I did not tell it—I missed the shilling, and gave her another, supposing I must have takenit—she said she would have a glass of ale—I gave her a glass and tenpenee—she gave me a shilling—I afterwards found I was a shilling short.
Cross-examined. Q. That was when the policeman came? A. Before that—I was telling my husband as the policeman came in.

JOHN WHITE (policeman, R 180). I took William, and said he was charged with receiving money of the woman—he said he had a right to receive what he liked from his wife—I found on him two sovereigns, sixteen shillings., twenty sixpences, thirty-two fourpenny-pieces, fourpence-halfpenny, and two ginger-beer bottles.
NOT GUILTY .

2191.
SARAH HICKLEY,
WILLIAM HICKLEY , and
JOHN HICKLEY , were again indicted for
stealing 1s.—2nd COUNT, stealing 2. balls of cotton, 2 groats, I penny, and 5 halfpence; the goods of
Charles Beaumont.

PHCEBK BEAUMONT . I am daughter of Charles Beaumont, who keep a toy-shop. On 9th Sept., about six at night, the female came and asked for a. ball of white cotton—she put a shilling down—I did not take it up because she asked me the price of so many things—the cotton came to a halfpenny—I gave it her with two fourpenny-pieces, one penny, and five halfpence—I exchanged the halfpenny ball for two farthing ones—I turned round and the shilling was gone—I asked if she had taken it up—she said, "No"—no one else was there—she left the shop with the change and cotton.

Cross-examined. Q. You never took up the shilling? A. No; the cotton was sold to her—I did not mean her to have it on trust—there was two shil lings in the till before she came, and the same after she left.

JOHN CARPENTER (policeman,) I saw Sarah go into the shop—the male prisoners waited thirty or forty yards off—she came out to them—I took her, and told her what it was for—she said people were great fools to give her change without having the money.
JOHN WHITE (policeman, R 180). I took William, and told him the charge—he said he had a right to receive what he liked from his wife—I searched him and found a sovereign and other money.
ANN GANDT . I searched Sarah, and found two balls and one real of cotton, and sixpence three-farthings.

SARAH—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

WILLIAM—
GUILTY . Aged 25.

JOHN—
GUILTY . Aged 46.

on 2nd Count.—
Confined Eight Months.

2192.
JAMES PAUL
, feloniously subbing, cutting and wounding
Thormas Crossley, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

JOSEPH JASPEE RICHARDS . I am a sergeant of Marines. On Sunday, 20th Aug., I was in the rear of the barracks at Woolwich—the men were having their supper—I saw Paul there, and Crossley standing up in front of him, and challenged him to fight—he was in the act of pulling his jacket off as I came up, and said I would put them both in the guard-room—Crossley said he had accused him of a thing he was not guilty of, and if he was any man he would stand up to fight—the prisoner was sitting down eating his

supper—I was taking Crossley away when he turned round, threw his jacket of and went to the prisoner, who was sitting on a stool, caught him by the throat with the left hand, and knocked him on the right side of the head—I went and took hold of Crossley to pull him off the prisoner—I found I had my hands full of blood—the prisoner was eating bread and cheese, and using a knife at the time—this is the knife (produced)—there is blood on it now.

THOMAS CROSSLEY . On Sunday night, 20th Aug., while having my sup
per, the prisoner accused me of having taking some money of another man, and I struck him—he took the knife he was eating with, and struck me in the back—I was taken to the hospital.

JAMES LAMMAY . On Monday morning, 21st Aug., I took the prisoner his breakfast in the guard-room—he asked me if there was any hope of Cross
ley coming out of the hospital—I told him I heard he was dead—he thanked God he was dead, for he wished his soul in heaven.
Prisoner. It is false.

THOMAS NELSON . I am surgeon of the Marines. I examined the pro
secutor and found, a wound about three-fourths of an inch in breadth, about two inches long, on the left shoulder bone—it was not dangerous—thisknife is very likely to have caused such a wound.

GUILTY of an Assault. Aged 19.—
Confined Six Months.

2193.
WILLIAM FEWKES
, stealing 1 brass joint, value 45s.; the goods of
our Lady the Queen.

DAVID STARK . I am a wheeler, in the Royal Arsenal, Woolwich. The prisoner was an artilleryman, employed there on alternate weeks, and paid extra—on 8th Sept. I was at work in shop 29—the prisoner came in—it was not his week to be there—he had this metal joint under his arm (produced)—I asked what he was going to do with it—he said, "I am going to make it walk—I said, "You are not going to be so foolish as to take that thing out of the place?"—he said, "I am," and threw it on the floor, went away, and came back in less than a minute with a basket, put it into it, and walked out of the shop—I told Kitchen.

GEORGE HENRY KITCHEN . I am a wheelwright, in Woolwich Arsenal, and had charge of the stores in shop 29—this joint was used by Colonel Colquhoun for experiments—it is the property of the Crown, and is worth 50s.

ROBERT HILL (policeman, R 42). I took the prisoner about a quarter-past one o'clock—his coat was covered with hemp—I saw a place where hemp was kept, and found this joint there, about a hundred yards from the shop, and a basket near it—he denied all knowledge of it.

GUILTY . Aged 33.—
Confined One Year.
(There was another indictment against the prisoner.)

2194.
JOHN COLLINS and
JOHN COLLINGS
, stealing 1 purse, value 1d.; and 1 sovereign and 8 half-sovereigns; the property of
Owen Lynch, from his person.

OWES LYNCH . I live at Eltham. On 6th Sept., between two and three o'clock in the afternoon, I was on my way home across Lee-green—the two prisoners came up to me—Collings said, "Countryman, will you have a share of a pot of beer?"—I said, "I have a pot here; you can have a drink out of

it"—they had part of it, and wanted me to fill another—I said I could not had no small change—he said, "You have no more"—I said, "I have but I do not wish to change"—I said I had eight half sovereigns, a sovere-and twopence beside—he asked me to let him have the twopence—I would not—he said, "I will lay you a pot of beer I show more money than you"—I said that might be, and he took out a quantity of silver out of his pocket—he put it into his pocket again—he then took out of another pocket handful of coppers, and silver amongst them, and he said, "Can't I show more than you?"—I then took out my half-sovereigns and showed him—he said, "Let me take care of that for you?"—I said, "No, I am capable of taking care of it "—we went on till we came to a private house—both the prisoners wanted me to go in, I would not—I went on about thirty rods and then sat down, and dropped asleep—I was awoke, and my purse and money were gone—I was not drunk.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. How much had you had? A. Not above two pots all day, one at Quin's, and another at the Lion and Lamb—I come from the north of Ireland—the prisoners are Irishmen, but they from another part—I am a labouring man—I got this money by hard labour—I have lived twenty-two years with one gentleman—I carried it about with me that day—I counted it, and put it into my pocket safe, when 1 was at the Little Tiger, at Lee-green—I got drowsy, and sat down to rest myself—I fell asleep; I was tired—a boy awoke me, and told me something—I had not spoken to anv one in croinsr from the Little Tijrer to the bank I at where down.

JOSEPH LOFT . I am an errand-boy, and live at Lee. I was going on an errand between three and four o'clock that day—I saw the prosecutor lying down asleep, and Collins was by his side—he had his hand in his waistcoat pocket—he then put it into his trowser's pocket—I then saw a brown pure in Collins's hand—he looked at it, got up, and walked a little way—he told me to go on—I said, "I shall not"—he then ran—I awoke the prosecute—I did not see Collings.

Cross-examined. Q. You lost sight of Collins? A. Yes—I had not seen him before—I saw him for about a minute—his back was towards me—there was no one passing—I gave information of this the same day—tie was a little boy with me—I carry out physic for Mr. Burrows, the doctor.

WILLIAM LORENTIEN . I was with Loft—I saw Collins put his band into the prosecutor's waistcoat-pocket—there was nothing there but a tobacco-but and a white handled knife—he then felt in his trowser's-pocket, and brought out a brown purse—he then got up and walked on, and then began to run—I did not see Collings.

Cross-examined. Q. How long afterwards did you see Collins again A. Next day, at the station—I was taken there by the policeman—the prisoners were both there together—the policeman said, "Is this the man?" I said, "Yes"—I can speak with certainty to his being the person—I know his face—I am a Spaniard—I live at Lee-green.
COURT. Q. Do you know Mrs. Quin's house? A. Yes—the prosecutor was sitting outside of her house, more than twice the length of the Court
JACOB DAVIES (policeman R 100). I took Collins—I found on him eight half-sovereigns, one sovereign, and one halfpenny—he was not drunt—I had not seen the prosecutor then.
ANN JORDAN . I saw the two prisoners at Mrs. Quin's house—I saw the prosecutor—go out, and Collins followed him—Collings stopped there—he
came out once or twice, and looked up the road—he could not see anybody from "'here he stood.

COLLINS—
GUILTY . Aged 30.

COLLINGS—
GUILTY . Aged 30.

2195.
JOHN HIPWELL
, stealing 3 sovereigns and 3 shillings; the moneys of
William Griffin; having been before convicted; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Nine Months.

2196.
JOHN WILLIAMS and
JAMES FRAZER
, stealing 10lbs. weight of pork, value 6s., the goods of
John Bay ley.

JOSEPH WHITE (policeman, R 330). On 25th Aug., about a quarter to eleren o'clock, I went to a lodging-house in High-street, Woolwich, and found the two prisoners there at supper, and in a chair in which Williams was sitting I found this leg of pork—he said he picked it up.
WILLIAM INCH . I live at Waterman-fields, Woolwich. On 25th Aug., about nine o'clock, I was near the prosecutor's shop—I saw the two prisoners on the opposite side of the road—I told Newman of it.

REUBEN NEWMAN . I am in the service of John Bailey. I saw the leg of pork safe about nine o'clock that evening—Inch spoke to me—I saw two persons across the way, who I believe were the prisoners—when they were gone, the pork was gone—ibis is it; I know it by a cut.
Frazer's Defence. We picked it up.

WILLIAMS—
GUILTY . Aged 25.

FRAZER—
GUILTY . Aged 26.

2197.
FRANCIS HENRY WILLES was indicted
for embezzlement.

BENJAMIN TEMPLING . I am in the service of the Waterman Steam-Packet Company as collector, at the City Pier, London-bridge—it is my duty to issue tickets to persons going up and down the river (it would be the pier
man's duty to receive them)—this book (produced) was in iny possession for that purpose on 30th Aug.—this ticket, No. 145, was issued from it that morning, for the purpose of going down the river.

Cross-examined by MR. PRENDEKGAST. Q. Do persons who come for a ticket sometimes change their minds after you have torn the ticket out of the book? A. Yes, it docs happen—if a person takes a ticket for Woolwich, and then say they will go to Greenwich, I give them a ticket for there, and give the other ticket to the next Woolwich passenger—I might do that in five minutes or in five hours—a ticket might be cast into the place where I stand, instead of being delivered at the station—I do not know that it has occurred at my place—if it does happen, those tickets would be given to the pier-man in a minute or two, or a little longer—the issuer of the tickets occa
sionally takes the tickets which the pier-man ought to receive; that is, by persons coming past the pier-man, and getting off at another part—those tickets ought not to get mixed with the others—ray stamp is No. 8—the prisoner would issue a different number—it would be impossible for the pier-man to distinguish the number on the ticket, but they know the colour of the ticket—we have different colours—the colour of that day was drab.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Are you quite sure this ticket left your pier that day? A. Yes; it was issued from my station, and I have the counterfoil.
ROBERT YOUNG . I am collector at the Westminster-bridge pier. I

produce a book, large "S" and little "s," No. 34—I had to issue checks of this book—I issued this ticket (produced) between nine and teno'clock in the morning on 30th Aug.—I have the counterfoil of it in my book, and the number all right—if it went to Woolwich it would pet down between and eleven—I have had—checks left with me instead of the pier-man—I have given them to the pier-man.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you give them directly? A. At the first opportunity—I cannot do it directly if I am busy—I might forget it—I am likely to make mistakes, and so is the prisoner.
MR. BALLANTINE. Q. Do you mean that you have issued the ticket you have received in that way to passengers? A. No, I will swear I never have.

WILLIAM READ . I am traveller to a woollen-draper at Aldgate. I went from Woolwich to London with my wife on 30th Aug., about half-past three by the Waterman steam-boat, No. 5—I saw the prisoner on the pier—I purchased two tickets of him for a shilling—one was "S. N. No. 145," and the other "S. S. 34, 72"—I observed they vvere rumpled—the prisoner asked where I was going—I told him to London, and he produced these two tickets to me—I had some communication with the captain on board, and I purchased two more tickets, and paid for them there—I returned to Wood wich the same night by the Black wall Railway, and saw Mr. Dixon, the superintendent—I gave him the tickets I bought of the prisoner—them I purchased of the captain I gave up to the pier-man on arriving.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe the third bell had struck for the passenger to go when you bought these tickets of the prisoner? A. Not the third; the second had—the moment the third bell sounds, the boat starts, then was no time to be lost.

JURY. Q. What induced you to show the tickets to the captain? A. The disorderly state in which they were—if these tickets were genuine the numbers would follow one another, and the prisoner would have had the check-book out on the slab, I did not see any—these are not backed in the same manner—one was issued on the 29th, the day before—I had seen are-ward of 20l. offered, but I had no recollection of it when I showed these ticket to the captain.

GEORGE WILLIAM BLANCHARD . I am cashier to the Waterman Steam Packet Company at Woolwich—the principal collector in the employ of the Company, Charles Collins Blane, is one of the proprietors, and there are were—it is the duty of the collectors to settle with me—this is one of the books that is given to the collectors to issue tickets from—they change colour from time to time—the prisoner had only to issue tickets that he tore out of the book—I have given him directions with respect to tickets which have been torn out of the book, not to sell those tickets till he had brought them to me, and had them counter-signed by me—he was directed to give the ticket out of a book which he had—he has brought tickets to me to be signed—that has been the course of his duty during the whole of the summer—if he had in his possession any tickets that had been issued at other stations, it was his duty to give them to the pier-man—there is constantly a pier-man at the Woolwich pier—on the morning of 31st Aug. the prisoner settled with me—he paid me 10d. as the balance of the preceding day's work—when I account with him, I go through his book, and ascertain the tickets issued, and then I require him account to me for the money—he said, previous to settling, that he had get into a mess through inadvertently selling two tickets, which had been given

to him by passengers landing at the pier—he did not say what he had done with the money—he did not pay the money to me, nor offer it—the stamp on the back of this ticket, "Aug. 29," is done by the collector when it is issued—here is the trace of a stamp on the front of this other ticket.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe he has fire or six different check books? A. Yes, for different parts—the colours on that day were drab 6d., pink 4d.—the checks of the other piers would only be different to these in the private nark—the pier-men receive letters from me about all the colours—they have only one set of stamps—I do not recollect the prisoner saying he should have to go before the board; he might—he did not offer me the money outside the office; Mrs. Willes did, about eight or nine o'clock the same morning.
JURY. Q. Did you know anything of his having made a mistake at the time he made that communication to you? A. Yes, the superintendent had told me of it half an hour before I saw the prisoner.

WILLIAM READ . I am master of the Waterman Steam Packet, No. 5—I recollect Mr. Read and his wife being on the boat on 30th Aug.—the prisoner's wife was on the boat at the same time—in consequence of what Mr. Read told me, I spoke to the prisoner when I returned to Woolwich at a quarter-past seven o'clock—I said, "A gentleman and his lady went up with me at half-past three, and they had two tickets which they said were not torn from the book, and I told him to buy two more on board the boat, and I sent the other two down to Mr. Dixon, the superintendent"—the prisoner said, "D ✗ it, you don't mean that, Read?" and he asked me if I knew where the person lived—I told him "No"—I told him I had to go round to the office to report it—I went to Mr. Dixon, and found he had heard of it by the gentleman who bought the tickets.

EVAN MILLS TRUELOVE . I was in the office on the evening of 30th Aug., about half-past seven o'clock, the prisoner gave me 12l. 10s. on account—he did not say anything about any tickets which he bad issued, except those from the book.
SAMUEL DIXON . I am superintendent of the Waterman Steam Packet Company—I saw the prisoner about a quarter before eight o'clock on the night of 30th Aug.—he did not speak to me.
NOT GUILTY .

2198.
MARY SMITH
, for a robbery, with violence, on
Charles Lawton, and stealing 2 half-crowns, his moneys; having been before convicted.

CHARLES LAWTON . I live in Upper Thames-street. On Saturday night, 2nd Sept., I was coming along Tooley-street towards London-bridge, and met the prisoner—she said, "How are you, my dear?"—I said, "Nicely"—she said, "Will you go along with me?"—I said, "No"—I did not see anybody with her—she immediately put her fingers to my throat, and while she had hold of me 1 received a blow under the ear, and fell—I received a kick under my rib, and another behind—a hand was put over my mouth, and I felt a hand go into my left trowsers-pocket, where I had two half-crowns—I had felt them just before, as I had my hand in my pocket when she met me—I was down a few minutes, and when J got up the prisoner was gone, and the half-crowns also—I gave information to the police, and went next night, Sunday, to an archway near London-bridge, where I saw the prisoner—I swear she is the person.
MICHAEL GROGAN (policeman, M 145). I took the prisoner, and told the charge—she denied it, and said she was at a public-house at the time.
Prisoner's Defence. I never saw the. man till the Sunday night.

WILLIAM GRIST (policeman 225). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction—(read—Convicted 21st Sept., 1846, of stealing from the person, and confined four months)—I was present at the trial—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2199.
JOSEPH COX was indicted
for uttering counterfeit coin, after; previous conviction; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged. 50.—
Confined Twelve Months.

2200.
EDWARD SHANOX
, for a robbery, with violence, on
John Roots and stealing 1 sovereign, 1 crown, 1 half-crown, 2 shillings, and 1 sixpence: his moneys.

JOHN ROOTS . I am a labourer, and live four miles from Rochester. I came up to town for the purpose of going into Guy's Hospital, where I am now of inmate—I arrived in London, where I am a stranger, on the afternoon 22nd Aug.—I had a sovereign and 29s. when I left home—between five and six o'clock in the afternoon, I went to a puhlic-hoose in High-site. Borough, where I had something to drink, and remained till the house clock—they could not let me have a bed there, and I left—I then felt my money safe—I had spent about 15s.—I went down the street as far as the bridge, see if I could get a lodging—I could not find one, and went and sat on the step of a door for about half an hour—while sitting there the prisoner and two others came up—he said, "What are you doing here? let us see what you have got about you"—I told him to go on, and let me alone—he took me by the collar, and struck me a very violent blow in the mouth, which made it bleed—he put his hand into my waistcoat and trowsers-pockets—my money was in my trowsers-pocket—I called out, "Police!"—the police-sergeant came up, I told him what had happened—the prisoner had then let go of me, and stood about two yards from me—he must have heard what I said to policeman—I told the policeman to take him in charge, he had struck me—i; immediately ran away—my money was goue.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. You had never seen the prisoner before? A. No—I was quite sober—I was sensible—I had not been drinking all day—I had had a pint or two of beer—I had been two days spending the 15s.—it was not because I was so drunk that they would not let me stop at the house; they had not room—I have not said I was not certain that this was the man—I never expressed a doubt as to his identity—I am certain he is the person—I had not lost the money when I sat down—I was dozing.
MR. CAARTEEN. Q. Were you in company with any one after you left the public-house until the prisoner came up? A. No—I am certain be is the man that struck me.

JOHN MENHINICK (police-sergeant, M 20). I was on duty, heard a cry of "Police!" and saw Roots standing at a door-way near the White Hartine, and the prisoner about two yards from him—Roots pointed to the prison, and said he had struck him violently, and had had his hand in his pocket and he gave him into custody—the prisoner ran away as fast as he could about 300 yards—I ran after him—I never lost sight of him till 1 took him—I brought him back to the prosecutor, who identified him—I searched him but found nothing on him.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you see some other persons near Roots when first went up? A. No—I did not see two other men run away—the prisoner said he knew nothing about it—Roots was quite sensible—he gave the same evidence that night that he gave the next day—he was not drunk.
NOT GUILTY .

2201.
JOHN CONNELL
, uttering counterfeit coin, after a previous conviction.

CALEB EDWARD POWELL . I am assistant-solicitor to the Mint. I produce a copy of the record of the conviction at this Court, in June sessions, 1847, of John Connell, of uttering counterfeit coin—I have examined it with the original; it is a true copy—(read.)
GEORGE BAINES (policeman, N 316). I was a witness against the prisoner in June, 1847—he is the same person.

GEORGE SOUTH . I keep the Duke's Head, Mint-street, Borough. The prisoner came there on 24th Aug., a little before twelve o'clock at night, and asked fora bottle of stout, which was 8d., and 2d. for the bottle until returned—he laid on the counter half a sovereign in payment—I laid down the change, then took up the half sovereign, rang it on my finger in the usual form, and also looked at it, and found it to be a good one—the prisoner said the stout was not for himself, and the parties were not in the habit of paying more than 6d.—I said I could not take 6d. for it, and therefore I must take it back again—I laid down the half-sovereign again, and he returned the change; and then be said, supposing the parties objected to pay the price, would I return the money again?—I said, "Yes; certainly"—I did not see what he did with the half-sovereign when he took it up—I gave him the change back, and he laid a half-sovereign on the counter again—I took it up, examined it, and found it was bad—he was then going out—I called after him before I left the bar—I then ran after him, with the half-sovereign in my hand—I lost sight of him—I returned in two or three minutes, and found him at the counter—I said, "Give me the half-sovereign you gave me first; I do not want this," showing him the money I had in my hand—he said, "What half-sovereign?"—I said, "You know very well what half-sovereign"—I told him it was a bad one—he did not say anything to that, but said he did not know what I meant, or words to that effect—two policemen came in, and I gave him in charge, and gave the half-sovereign to Delany.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. What did you do with the second half-sovereign, when you ran out? A. I kept it in my hand till I gave it to Delany—I marked it.

JOHN DELANY (policeman, M 100.) I went into the prosecntor's house with Fielding—the prisoner was there—I heard South say, "This is not the half-sovereign you gave me first; it was a good one, and this is a bad one"—the prisoner said, "If it is bad, I know nothing about it; I got it from my brother to come for a bottle of stout"—I asked if he had got any more money?—he said, "No"—South gave me the half-sovereign produced—I and Fielding took the prisoner into custody—he had his back to the counter, facing me, and I observed him move his mouth, as if attempting to swallow something—I immediately took hold of him by the throat, to cause him to throw up what-ever he had in his mouth—I then put my finger into his mouth—he bit me, and caused the blood to flow—he succeeded in swallowing whatever he had in his mouth, and fell on the ground and rolled about as if he was in pain—
it was a minute or two before he spoke—I afterwards took him to the station, searched him, and found no money on him.

Cross-examined. Q. How many other people were there? A. Four five; but the struggle between me and the prisoner caused more to come to the door; the prisoner said, "My brother gave it me; if it was wrong do you think I should have come back again?"

JOHN FIELDING (policeman, M 241). On 24th Aug. I accompanied Delany and took the prisoner into custody—he said to Mr. South, "Is it likely I should come into your house again if I had given you a bad half-soverign?—I am rather deaf—I heard something gingle in the prisoner's mouth, and told Delany; ho seized hold of him by the throat—he threw himself down and a quantity of blood came from his mouth.
Cross-examined. Q. Did it sound like the rattling of money? A. Yes,

CALEB EDWARD POWELL
re-examined. I act as inspector of counter coin to the Royal Mint, in the absence of Mr. Field, the regular inspector—this is a counterfeit half-sovereign.

GEORGE SOUTH
re-examined. When the prisoner returned to the house, he had laid the change on the counter—he said, "There is the change"—I took it up and said, "Well, that is of course all I require."

2202.
MARY ANN WEST
, feloniously killing and slaying
Elizabeth Shields: she was also charged on the Coroner's inquisition of the like offence.
JOHN SHIELD . The deceased was my mother—her name was Elizabeth Shields.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Is the prisoner your sister?. A. Yes; she always behaved with the greatest kindness to my mother.

MARTHA FOSTER . I am nine years' old, and live with my parents, at 10, Upper Marsh—I know the prisoner—on Wednesday, 30th Aug., about half past four, I saw the old lady in the back-yard of Mr. Hemmings' house—she lived in the back parlour there—my sister was with me—I saw the prisons by her back-door—she was talking with the old lady, who was sitting on basket—I did not hear what they said—the prisoner was in one yard and the old lady in another—there was a small fence between them—I was in No. 10, where the prisoner was—after they had been talking some time, I saw the prisoner pick up half a brick from the stones, and throw it at her mother—it hit her at the back of the head—she had just got off the seat, and was coming towards the paling—she was stooping down when the brick struck her—her head was all over blood—she then went into the passage, and the prisoner met her there—I heard a noise in the passage.

Cross-examined. Q. Was it after the brick was thrown that the old lady went close to the paling? A. No, before; she did not try to do any
thing—she called her daughter a bad name, and said she had robbed her of 10l.—I did not see the blood on her head till after she came from the police-court.

RICHARD HEMINC . I live at 11, Upper Marsh. The deceased live in our back-parlour for three weeks—she was a person of intemperate habits—the prisoner lived next door—on 30th Aug., about four o'clock, I heard a noise in the passage—I went down, and saw the prisoner and deceased struggling together—the deceased had hold of the prisoner's hair—they backward's, and the back of the deceased's head came heavily on the bottom

step in the passage—the prisoner fell upon her—I endeavored to separate Tern but could not—the deceased still held hold of the prisoner's hair—I sent for the police, and when I went in again, the deceased was up—the back part of her head was bleeding—her cap was completely deluged with blood—he gave the prisoner in charge for the assault—next morning her face was very much swollen and bruised, and her eyes black—she kept about till Sunday morning—a doctor was called in on Monday, and she died on Thursday.

Cross-examined. Q. Was the prisoner trying to get from her? A. It appeared so to me; she was calling for her to loose her—they were down together for three or four minutes, the deceased clenching her tight with both hands—she was drunk, and always has been drunk ever since she lived in my room—she was very troublesome, particularly to the prisoner—I believe she was endeavouring to get her into her room on this occasion—she was kind to her mother—the mother was always calling her bad names, and accusing her of robbing her of 10l.—the prisoner is married—no one attended to the deceased but her.

THOMAS NORMAN (policeman, L 23). I was sent for, and saw the prisoner and deceased—they were standing in the passage when I got in—blood was running from the back part of deceased's head, and her face was beaten all across—she gave the prisoner in charge for robbing her of 10l., and for assaulting her—as I was taking her to the station, she said, "Ah the d----old wretch, I will have her life now before I have done with her."

SARAH HEMMINGS . On 30th Aug. I went into the passage, hearing a noise, and saw the deceased lying on the floor with her head on the step, and having hold of the prisoner's hair—they remained in that position five minutes—I said to the prisoner, "Shall I send for a policeman, or come to your assist
ance?"—she said, "Pray send for a policeman"—I went to look for one, and when I came back they were up—the deceased's face was very much swollen, but that it always was—it was more swollen than usual, and a little black.

Cross-examined. Q. I believe she was constantly drunk? A. I never saw her sober; she fell about very much—she had a very awkward fall a week before—she was drunk at nine o'clock this very morning—I heard her accuse the prisoner of robbing her of 10l.—I never saw the prisoner drunk—she was always kind and attentive to her mother.

SARAH CRESS . I live at No. 12. On 30th Aug. I came through the passage, and saw the prisoner and her mother there—the prisoner asked her for the key of her room—the deceased said, "No, I will not give it you, you w----, you have robbed me enough"—she was drunk—the prisoner then pushed her down—she feil back, and her head came against the step—the prisoner said, "Now will you give me the key?"—she said, "No," and called her a w----again several times—the prisoner then stooped down, and beat her across the face and eyes with her double fist—Mr. and Mrs. Hemmings were in and out of the passage at the time, but they did not stop long—a, young man who stood there, said, "Don't beat your mother any more "—the prisoner said, "Shall I strangle her, and rid the world of such a monster as she is?"—she was standing at that time, and her mother was lying on her back—she had her bonnet on, and when she got up I observed blood on it—her face was very much beaten and bruised, and her eyes were black a quarter of an hour afterwards.
Cross-examined. Q. Are you married? A. I am; I live with my husband—I have repeatedly seen deceased drunk.

RICHARD HEMMINGS
re-examined. I have heard what this witness has
stated—I heard nothing of the kind—I must have heard it if it had been—I only left the passage to go to the street-door to see if the policeman coming—I was not out of hearing.

SARAH HEMMINGS
re-examined. I did not hear any of these words used—I should have heard them if they had been used; it is a long passage—room is at the end, but the door was not closed—there were several boys and girls in the passage, and there was a great noise—I saw Mrs. Cress there—I could not distinguish all that was said.

MICHAEL KEATING O'SHEA . I am a surgeon at 17, Mount-street, Lan
beth. I was called to deceased on—4th Sept.—she was labouring under sipelas—I saw her once on Monday, twice on Tuesday, and once on Wednes-day, and on Thursday she died—I made a post-mortem examination company—with Mr. Smith, the medical officer of the parish—erysipe lasthe immediate cause of death—the scalp was rather soft: that would in serous effusion, which would be the result of previous inflammation—I think that erysipelas, acting on a feeble frame in a broken-up constitution, the sequence of intemperate habits, with a tendency to delirium tremens, was the immediate cause of death—I found a lacerated wound at the back of head, and a contusion about the size of a half-crown—they were probably the result of two injuries; a broken brick would be likely to produce the one and any obtuse substance the other—there were contusions about the and eyes—I think all these circumstances together were sufficient to produce erysipelas—I should say it was produced by violence—I do not attribute: to the blow on the back of the head, but more to the contusions about the face and temple—it certainly might be produced by intemperate habits alone—I think the violence would necessarily accelerate it—erysipelas might not have ensued immediately on the violence—if it had existed for three weeks, I should have expected to find suppuration, but there was none—I think it had commenced four or five days previously.
(The prisoner received a good character.)
NOT GUILTY .

2203.
CHARLES TAYLOR,
GEORGE COX,
WILLIAM POOLE,
CHARLES GIBBS,
THOMAS HERBERT,
WILLIAM WINSPERE
THOMAS IRONS,
JAMES PROWTON,
HUGH CONWAY,
ALEX
ANDER HARBY,
JAMES JOHN NORTON,
SAMUEL HARBY , and
SAMUEL MORGAN , were indicted for
unlawfully conspiring to excite insurrection and riot, and to obstruct, by force, the execution of the laws and the preservation of the public peace, and to procure arms and ammunition for that purpose; to which the following prisoners pleaded
GUILTY :

POOLE—Aged 38. HERBERT—Aged 21. IRONS—Aged 33.—
Con
fined Eighteen Months.
WINSPERE—Aged 26. PROWTON—Aged 29. CONWAY—Aged 27; and MORGAN, aged 22.—
Confined Two Years. All
fined 10l.,
and to enter into their own recognizances in 20l., and find the sureties of 10l. each, to keep the peace for Fire Years.

TAYLOR, COX. GIBBS, ALEXANDER, and SAMUEL HARBY, and JAMES JOHN NORTON, who pleaded
NOT GUILTY ,
entered into their own recognizances, in 50l. each, to appear and take their trial upon that indictment when called upon.
(None of these defendants were called upon to plead to the indictment for felony.)

2204.
MARY ANN MARTIN
, stealing 1 watch, value 5l.; the goods of
Jonathan Wearing, from his person.

JONATHAN WEARING . I live at George-terrace, New Kent-road. On Thursday morning, about two o'clock, I met the prisoner and another, about ten yards from Waterloo-bridge—they wished me to pay for their going over—I refused, but just as I was paying my fare they passed me, and I paid for them—they requested me to go up Earl-street with them—I refused—they hustled me; I felt a jerk, and missed my watch from my waistcoat-pocket—the prisoner ran—two men, who I had observed before, came up squaring at me, and said, "You are a pretty fellow to have connection with a female in a public thoroughfare," and prevented my following her—I escaped, and followed her—I turned a corner, and found her in charge—she gave me my watch—this is it (produced.)
Cross-examined by MR. METCALFE. Q. Where had you been? A. To Tottenham Court-road.
JAMES POSSEE (policeman, L 60). I was on duty, and saw the prisoner cross. Waterloo-road, with her bonnet in her hand, and Wearing following her—I slopped her—she gave him this watch in my presence.
JAMES FROST (policeman, L 56). About half-past four o'clock in the morning I picked up this watch-ring.

GUILTY . Aged 27.—
Confined Six Months.

2205.
CHARLES SMITH
, stealing 1 coat, value 12s.; the goods of
George Searle and another, his masters.
HEKEY AUSTRALIA THORNTON . I live at Camberwell. In the beginning of April I left my coat in a cupboard at Mr. Searle's—I lost it—this is it (produced).

Cross-examined by MR. MELLER. Q. Had you the key of the cupboard? A. No; I used to leave it with Mr. Searle, and charged him with, the loss—another gentleman kept his coat in the same locker—there was only one key—I think he had it, as Mr. Searle had not—the constable gave me the coat—I know it by its appearance, and by one button having been torn, which I had sewn up—I found the cupboard doors open—the prisoner used to get the boats ready for us.
EDWARD FREDERICK WINSTONE . I am clerk to George Searle and another, boat-builders. The prisoner was in their service, and had opportunities of going to this room—we missed this coat, and others.

Cross-examined. Q. How many other persons has Mr. Searle employed there? A. Only the prisoner and another in that yard—the prisoner has been there five or six years, I believe; but he has been dishonest once before—I have had no quarrel with him—I have not seen him wear this coat—it is a superior one.
JOHN TIMOTHY HUGHES (policeman). The prisoner gave me his address—I went to his house, and found this coat on the bed.

GUILTY . Aged 33.—
Confined Four Months.

2206.
JOSEPH ELDRIDGE, alias
JOSEPH IREDALE
, stealing 1 hand kerchief, value 1s.; the goods of
Edgar Walter Morton, from his person; having been before convicted.
EDGAR WALTER MORTON . I am a master, in a school. On 24th Aug. I

felt a tug at my pocket, in the Waterloo-road, and saw the prisoner behind me with my handkerchief in his hand—this is it (produced)—he threw through an area-railing—I caught him—he struggled, and said he had not taken it—I took him to the area—he struck rue, and bolted down a bye-street—he was stopped.

HENRY STREET , I am a porter, at the South Western Railway. I saw the prisoner running, and crying, "Stop thief!"—I followed him half a mile—he used great violence—I got assistance—he said there were no d----d companions, or else they would rescue him from me—I gave him in charge.
SAMUEL CHART (policeman, L 14). I took the prisoner—he denied the dare.
Prisoner's Defence. I was running after the lad who picked the pocket.
WILLIAM ATLEE (policeman, L 110). I produce a certificate of the pri-soner's conviction from Mr. Straight's office—(read—Convicted July, 1845 and confined one year.)

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Eighteen Months.

2207.
HENRY CURSON
, stealing 9 sovereigns, 6 shillings, 1 sixpens, and 2 pence; the moneys of
William Atwooll Bennett.

THAMAR BENNETT . I am the wife of William Atwooll Bennett, the mate of the Clementine, plying between this country and Ireland. We live at 3, Queen-street, Horsleydown—the prisoner is my cousin by marriage—I left him, his wife, and my sister, Miss Curtis, in charge of the house, and went with my husband to Ireland—I was in the room with them on the evening I left, and counted out nine sovereigns, 6s., and 8d. on the table, folded it in a receipt for the rates, and asked them to be kind enough to pay that to the landlord, when he called—both the prisoner and his wife said they would do—the wife took it up—they were to sleep in the front-room, first-floor—I returned on 16th Aug., between three and four o'clock—the prisoner was not at home—he came in about four—he told me I had no occasion to sit up, for it would be very late when he came in, he would take the street-door key—I objected to that, and said my sister should sit up for him—I went to bed between ten and eleven, in the back-room, second-floor—I heard no thieves in the house—soon after eleven I heard a knock, and the door unlocked—my sister came up—I went down, and saw the prisoner come in, with two con
stables—next morning I gave the prisoner notice to leave—he said, "I have written to my father concerning the money that was lost last night"—I said "What money?"—he did not answer me—I said, "Have not you paid the rent?"—he said, "No"—I asked if the landlord had called—he said, "Yes; once," but his wife was not in, and he could not get the money—I asked him where the receipts were—he said the robbers had left them, and he gave them me.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. Have not you accused the people of the house of stealing a sable cape? A. No; I lost it in the street.

ELIZABETH CURTIS . I was left in the house with the prisoner and his wife—I was present on 10th July, when the money was counted out—Mrs. Bennett returned on 16th Aug.—the prisoner went out afterwards—I sat up for him—no one Lad broken open the house then—he came home about half-past eleven—I opened the door—he said, "Make haste and shut the door; I have just seen two persons jump from the top of the door"—there is a cill there, but the window is much higher up—I do not think people coula get in at the window from there—the prisoner took up a poker and said, "You stop here while I go up stairs"—he took no light—in about a minute be called me up, and said, "They have been in my room"—he went to his box

and said, "They have taken something out"—he said it was ransacked, and one window was open—he went out for a policeman—he came back in five minutes, and could not find one—he went out again, and came back with two in about five minutes.

Cross-examined. Q. Did a sailor come in Mrs. Bennett's absence? A. Yes; about a fortnight before she came home—he had left his clothes there in Jan., before Captain Bennett went away, and called for them—the prisoner offered to let him hang them to dry in the yard—he had not asked—he went into the prisoner's room—the prisoner's wife was with him—I afterwards found the clothes were gone.

WILLIAM WELLS . I live at Elizabeth-terrace, Hackney-road, and collect rents for Mrs. Dixon. I called for half a year's rent at 3, Queen-street, Horsleydown, on 13th July, III but the rates were to be deducted, and I was to receive 9l. 6s. 8d.—the prisoner opened the door, but not wide enough for me to stand on the cill—he said, "I have got the half-year's rent for you, but my wife is out, and has got the key, and I cannot give it you"—he stood trembling—he said there was no one in the house to fetch the key, but I heard people talking and walking—I met him the next week, in Tooley-street—I should not have seen him, but he spoke to me, and said, if I would come back to Mr. Bennett's house, he would pay me part of the rent—I said, "No; why do you want to pay me part of it, when you said last week that you had the whole?"—he said he had not received the whole, he had 2l. to receive of the lodgers, to make it up, which he had not got—on 15th Aug. I called again—he came to the door, and asked me to walk in—I went into the back parlour—he held his hands up, and said, "A serious thing," or a "Dreadful thing has occurred; here has been a robbery in the house, and I shall be ruined"—he was shaking, and appeared very much, confused—Mrs. Bennett afterwards gave me these receipts (produced).
Cross-examined. Q. He was a stranger to you? A. Yes.

MARY ANN CORNWALL . I am the wife of John Cornwall, of John-street, Horsleydown. On 13th July I took tea with the prisoner and his wife, at Mrs. Bennett's—I heard a knock at the door—the prisoner went and came back—his wife asked who was there—he said, "The landlord called for the rent"—she said, "Why don't you pay?"—he said, "The landlord is going to send some people next door, to do some repairs; he will be there in a day or two, and it does not signify till then"—on 16th Aug. the prisoner came to my house, and told me Mrs. Bennett had come back—I said I should go down after tea—he said, "You might go up stairs, and see if the box is locked, for the money is in it, in my room"—I said I should do no such tinner, what would Mrs. Bennett think, if I went into his room—he said, I could go without her knowing it—I said, "Go yourself"—he said, "No," put his hand into his pocket, and pulled out a very small key, and said, "I know it is locked; here is the key," and went away—I understood him to speak of a work-box.

Cross-examined. Q. Was the sister at home when you went there? A. No—the prisoner had told me not to tell Mrs. Bennett that the landlord had called—that was on the day she came home—I did keep a public-bouse at Ipswich, but gave it up, because it would not keep me—my license was taken away.

JOSHUA GOLDON (policeman, H 87). On 16th Aug., about eleven o'clock at night, the prisoner came and took me to 3, Queen-street, and said on the way that a robbery had been committed there, and he saw two men like seamen jump from the door-ledge; that there was a purse, with 11l. in it, in

the room they jumped from, and he expected it was gone—I examined the front room, but found no appearance of persons having broken in—the window immediately above the street door was open—I told the prisoner to see if he missed anything—he said he could miss nothing at present—there was a work-box on the bed upset, and the contents scattered about—he looked into it, and found a purse, and said, "Here is the purse, but the money is gone out of it"—I searched the next room; but he said he could miss nothing till his wife came home—I was to call next night to take an inventory of the things—I called next night, and he described three pairs of shoes which he had lost—I did not see whether the work-box had a key.
Cross-examined. Q. Are there flower-pots on the ledge over the door A. I saw none—I do not think they would stand, it is not level—a person might step on it, but it would be dangerous.

HENRY HUNT (policeman, M 82). The prisoner was given in my charge—he said to Mr. Bennett, "I hope you will not charge me"—he said he should—the prisoner said, "If you will not, I will take you to a place in Tooley-street where I can get the amount of money."
NOT GUILTY .

2208.
HENRY CURSON was again indicted
for stealing 1 time-piece and 2 spoons, value 9l., the goods of
William Attwood Bennett, in his dwelling-house.
(Elizabeth Curtis, William Wells, Mary Ann Cornwall, and Joshua Golden, gave the same evidence as in the former case.)

THOMAS BENNETT After the officers came to my house on Thursday, I missed my gravy-spoons from the cheffioneer, and a time-piece from a draw—no one knew I had left them—the drawer and cheffioneer were not locked—none of the property has been traced.

GUILTY . Aged 24.—
Confined One Year.

2209.
WILLIAM BROWN,
GEORGE JONES , and
ELIZABETH JOHNSON
, stealing 1 purse, I shilling, and 3 half-crowns, the property of
Harriett Blanchard, from her person; Brown having been before convicted.

JOHN SPITTLE (City-policeman, 671). On Saturday evening, 9th Sept., about a quarter-past six o'clock, I saw the prisoners together in Bishopsgate-street, going towards London-bridge, and followed them to the Walworth-road—I there saw the prosecutrix coming towards the Elephant and Castle from Camberwell—the prisoners followed her—Brown put his left hand into be: pocket, took it out, put it in again, and took it out with something in it—he put her handkerchief back into her pocket, and passed something to Jones—Johnson stood behind, concealing what the others were about—I told the prosecutrix, and then went after the prisoners, and with the assistance of another constable I took all three—I am sure they are the persons—I knew Brown and Jones before—I said, "I want you"—they said, "What for?'—I said, "For robbing a lady of a purse"—Brown said I was mistaken—Jones said he had not been near the lady—I went back with them to the lady, and she said, in their presence, she had lost a purse and three half-crowns.
PATRICK DANEY (policeman, 245). I took Johnson—she said she had only just met the others—I found on her three half-crowns, and these combs, which she said were her own.
HARRIETT BLANCHARD . I am single. About seven o'clock, on this night I was in the Walworth-road, and, in consequence of what a policeman told me
I missed my purse, containing three half-crowns—I had had it safe half an hour before.
MICHAEL HAYDON (City policeman). I produce a certificate—(read—William Brown, convicted Feb., 1847, of stealing from the person; confined six months)—I was present—Brown is the person.

BROWN—
GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Transported for Seven Years.

JONES—
GUILTY . Aged 19.

JOHNSON—
GUILTY . Aged 18.

2210.
DANIEL MORRIS
, feloniously cutting and wounding
Jane Ann Morris, with intent to do her some grievous bodily harm.

JANE ANN MORRIS . The prisoner is my husband—I now live at 5, Eden-streef, Holborn. About twelve weeks ago, in May, I came home to where we lived, in Webber-street, between nine and ten o'clock at night—my husband was sitting by the fire—he asked the little boy, who is twelve years old, what the time was—he said, ten minutes to ten, I think—my husband spoke about the impropriety of my not being at home before him, and asked me for money—he accused me of being drunk as usual—I denied it—I was not—he asked for some supper—I said it was out of my power to give it—aggravation took place between us to the extreme—I accused him of being drunk—he had begun to drink at six o'clock in the morning—he asked if I could not furnish him with a sovereign next day—I said it was out of my power—he accused me of many things, family matters—he had the poker in the fire, clearing it—I found him in the act to strike me—he made after me, and struck me on the arm—I believe I put my arm up—I do not know where he struck at—I may have told the Magistrate I put my arm up to guard my head, and got the blow on my arm—I heard a noise, as if a basket was broken—there was no basket there—I afterwards found my arm was broken—I fell—I do not know what made me fall—I was then struck again on my legs with a poker, which my husband had in his hand—I was struck four or five times on the arm—I pulled a chair near me—I cannot say whether that saved me—my husband broke it with the poker—some one came in—I was taken to the hospital, and have been there ever since.

AIEXANDER FREEMANTLE . I am clerk to a merchant, at 64, Webber-street—the prisoner and his wife lived at 65. On 31st May, between ten and eleven o'clock, I was in my back parlour, and heard very loud blows in rapid succession, and screams of "Murder!" and "Save me!"—I went, burst the door open, and found Mrs. Morris weltering in blood, and the prisoner stand
ing over her with part of a broken poker—I said, "For God's sake, you are not going to kill the woman!"—he said, "She deserves it"—I saw that her arm was broken, and the elbow dislocated—there was blood on the ground—the police came in, and I gave him in charge—he seemed very cool and col
lected—he put his fingers in his waistcoat-pockets, he gave one of his chil
dren half-a-crown to pay for something, and took his snuff-box from the shelf and put it in his pocket, as if nothing had occurred.

JOHN PAYNE (policeman, L 156). I heard a cry of "Police!" went to the house, and found the female behind the door on the ground, and bleeding from the elbow—I lifted her up, rested her arm on a chair, and put a shawl on it—it was broken—I said to the prisoner, "Good God, man, you have murdered "our wife!"—he said nothing—I found this chair-leg there, and a broken Poker, one part in the fire-place and the other on the ground—I found this chair split.
RICHARD BAKWELL . I am dresser at St. Thomas's Hospital. Mrs. Morris was brought there on the night of 31st May—she had several bruises about
the body, a cut on the left hand, her arm was broken in two places and her elbow dislocated.

MATTHEW FRENCH WAGSTAFFE . I am a surgeon. On 31st May, about half-past eleven o'clock at night, I saw Mrs. Morris in the front room in Webber-street, lying on the ground—her arm was broken at the elbows and fore-arm—there were wounds on her legs near the knees—I thought one leg was broken, but it was not—I put the arm right for the time, and had her taken to the hospital—I have seen her there several times—she has left two or three weeks, but is still an out-patient.

Prisoner's Defence. I remonstrated with my wife for leaving the children she began to abuse me, and accused me of cohabiting with my daughter; I lost all command of myself, and what I did afterwards 1 cannot count for.

JOHN PAYNE
re-examined. The prisoner was sober—he did not appear in a passion.

p.rs: GUILTY. Aged 45.—Recommended to mercy by Jury and

div1.p:
Prosecutrix.—
Confined Eighteen Months, and to enter into his own recog
nizance in 50l. to keep the peace for two years.

2211.
JOHN SHARPE
, unlawfully keeping an open shop, in which were a quantity of indecent prints and books.

GUILTY .—
Confined Twelve Months, and
fined 20l.

2212.
JOHN BACON and
ELLEN BENBOW
, stealing 30 yards of cloth, value 3l.; the goods of
Robert Simmonds; and
MARY DOUCH and
ELIZABETH OWEN
, feloniously receiving part of the same.

ROBERT SIMMONDS . I am a woollen manufacturer, of Friday-street—Bacon was in my service—he left on 16th Sept.—I did not see him again till he was in charge—this woollen cloth is mine, and was in my warehouse—I did not miss it till he was in charge—it is not made for any other house.

Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. How long did he live with you? A. One month the last time, but he had been with me twice before—the first time was in the autumn of 1847—I do not manufacture my own goods, they are made for me at Huddersfield—I bought these of Tolson and Dalton, of Huddersfield—there is no private mark on them—I know them by the quality and pattern—I saw it again at the station before I knew it was lost—I cannot say how much I had sold, without looking at my books—I had sold some seven people—when I identified it, I could not tell but what I might have sold it.

ELIZABETH METCALF . I am the wife of George Metcalf, of Reynold's-row, Southwark. On 16th Sept., between seven and eight o'clock in the evening, I was at my door, and saw Bacon with a brown paper parcel under his arm—he took it into Benbow's house—Douch and Benbow stood at the door, went in, and shut the door—presently Douch went out, and afterwards came back, and went out with Bacon and Benbow to a public-house—they came back again—they went out again, and returned—Bacon and Benhow went into the house, and stopped for an hour—I heard Benbow say to Doucb, "It is all right, I have given it to her in the passage."

Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. Had they anything with them when they went out to the public-house? A. No—they were there about fire minutes—I did not know what the conversation referred to, but when Bacon came out he had no parcel with him.

ELLEN NAIGLE . I live in Chapel-place, Southwark. On 16th Sept., between nine and ten o'clock. I was at my door, and saw Benbow come from—her house with a large paper parcel, and give it to Owen, at 1, Chapel-place—it

was about the size of this, and had paper over it—Owen had another house, at 8, Chapel-place—they carried it across from No. 1 to 8, I am sure it was the same parcel, and then both went away down Suffolk-street—Wright came and asked roe some questions—I afterwards saw Owen in custody—Wright went into No. 8, and brought out a large parcel, apparently the same.
Cross-examined by MR. PRENDERGAST. Q. Do you keep a house there? A. Yes, a house of accommodation, No. 4.
Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. I suppose Douch is an unfortunate girl? A. Yes.

WILLIAM BOYCE . I am in the service of Mr. Reynolds, 3 pawnbroker. On 16th Sept., between nine and ten o'clock, I received notice from the police—Benbow and Douch came and offered this small remnant of plaid in pledge—I asked where they got it—Benbow said Douch had brought it at Farr's, meaning a linen-draper's shop in the Borough—Douch nodded her head—I said I must detain it, and asked them to look in again in half an hour—when they were gone I sent for the police—they did not come again, but they sent twice.
Cross-examined by MR. SLEIGH. Q. Had you seen Douch before? A. Yes, and Benbow also—I can not say which offered it.

JOHN WRIGHT (policeman, M 63). On 16tb Sept. I received information, and informed Boyce—he sent for me at half-past nine—I went to 8, Revel's-row, and took Benbow and Douch—I searched the place—Benbow said, "What are you looking for?"—I said, "For some more of the plaid"—she said, "You won't find any more"—I went to Chapel-street, and saw Naigle—she gave me information—I went to I, Chapel-place, Owen's house, and told her I wanted a brown paper parcel left there by Benbow—she said there was no brown paper parcel left there that night, there was one the night before, containing a pair of stays—she took me over to No. 8, opened a cup
boards—door, and showed me a parcel containing this length of plaid—I took her—I found Bacon at his mother's, in Lock's-fields—I said I had taken some girls for stealing some plaid, and they said he had given it to them—he said, "That is right, I did," that he had received it from his mother, who had it from his uncle, who was lost in the Ocean Monarch, going to America—he said before the Magistrate he picked it up in a gutter, and when he was com
mitted for trial he said he found it in Friday-street—Douch said she did receive it from him, and she was to give 14s. for it.
Cross-examined by MR. O'BRIEN. Q. Did the Magistrate hear him say he found it in a gutter? A. Yes—I told him who the females were—I said one was his cousin—I do not think I mentioned her name.

Cross-examined by MR. PRJENDERGAST. Q. I believe Owen keeps a house where these young women go? A. Yes—I searched the place, but did not find anything—she took me from there to No. 8—I saw the parcel the moment the cupboard-door was opened—it was not locked, only buttoned—it was a house where women go.
NOT GUILTY .

2213.
SELINA SINCLAIR
, stealing. 24 spoons, 6 forks, and other articles, value 23l. 15s.; the goods of
Benjamin Charles Jones, her master, in his dwelling-house.

BENJAMIN CHARLES JONES . I live in Harder's-road, Peckham—I am a tobacco-merchant, in Moorgate-street—the prisoner came into my service six
teen or seventeen months since as a general servant, by the name of Mary nation—I was very little at the house at Camberwell—she had the charge

of it—in Jan. last I left the house for eight or ten days, and left the prisoner and the groom in it—I returned about the 3rd or—4th Feb., and the prisoner was gone—I never saw her again till she was in custody—I missed a slice, silver spoons, and other things—they were in her charge—I supposed she kept them in her own room—I had seen some of them a few days before I left—I was hut seldom at the house, and only in quired a spoon or two myself—I missed also some clothes, shirts, and things of that description—the tiling I missed cost considerably above 100l.—on the Sunday morning following I received by post a package done up as a letter, which contained the outside of a housewife, in which were several duplicate—I immediately recognized the housewife, I had seen it about the place and on the table—I gave the policeman the duplicates—I have seen the articles since, and know them to be mine.

Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE Q. When did you put these things into her charge? A. immediately she came; I counted them over with her—the plate has no crest or initial, but some of them have marks by which I am identify them—my establishment consisted of the prisoner and the groom—the prisoner was allowed a person to assist her when she required it, for which I paid—she provided the housekeeping—she had a book in which she put down—she had to pay for it—I gave her money in hand invariably, but a other times I put them on board-wages—I gave her money when she came to me—when I was not at my residence or my place of business, I was traveling on my own business—the tobacco business was not the only business on which I travelled—I give readings from Shakespeare, and occasionally play—I have done business in the betting line—I have unfortunately been a sporting man—I never stopped above a few days at the races—I left money with the pri
soner when I went from home—when I came back, if she had run deficient, I gave her more—she had to keep herself and the groom—she never had to wait above a day or two, when she told me she wanted money I gave, it to Ler—Benjamin Charles Jones is the name I have always been known by in business—I have always takten my mother's name—my father's name was Jacobs—I changed mv name to Jones when I was quite a vouth—there new was any intimacy between me and the prisoner—I swear that we have never been in any other position but that of master and servant.

ALEXANDER INNIS BURGESS . I am a pawnbroker, in Clarence-place, Cam
berwell—I know the prisoner—in Oct. 1847, she pawned a tablespoon, a teaspoon, and a fork; and in Dec. these snuffers and tray—I took in this mantle of her, and this cruet-frame—they were all pawned by her in the name of Smith.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you know where she was living? A. No other
wise than she told me—she seemed rather to be the mistress than the servant—she was very respectable—I do not know Mr. Jones except by hearsay—I have heard a good deal of him.

HENRY HOLTO . (policeman, P 104). In consequence of information I looked after the prisoner, and found her in St. George's-in-the-East, on the 10th or 11th Aug., in custody of another policeman—she said, if Mr. Jones had done as he ought he would have got the things out, and said on more about it, and she should not have done as she had, but for finding herself four months none in the family way by Mr. Jones, and she pawned the things for the purpose of supplying the house with food, in consequence of Mr. Jones not allowing sufficient to go it with—she said she sent the duplicate back Mr. Jones would have got tin things out and said nothing about it—her

intention was to go to Newcastle, her native place, under the idea of uettin the money and returning the things, and had it not been for busy people one would have known about it—the prisoner had absconded, and was away for six months—the property was given up by the pawnbrokers by order of the Magistrate.
Cross-examined. Q. I believe she told you that she had miscarried? A. Yes; and that she came back for the purpose of looking after her daughter.

MR. BALLANTINE to MR. BOUGESS. Q. Did the prisoner redeem articles? A. Yes; she has frequently redeemed some of these—some of them have been in my house four or five times—this mantle has been in two or three times—it was pawned once with a red coat, and once with a blue coat.

THOMAS TAYLOR . I am groom to the prosecutor. I do not know any
thing about these articles.

Cross-examined. Q. Do you remember the prisoner coming into your master's service? A. Yes; the servant who was there before the prisoner was a young woman named Mary—I was only there about a week when she left—ray master was much out, sometimes for a week, sometimes for three or four days—I believe at one time he was out for three or four weeks—I do not know whether he left anything for the house—the prisoner had to provide—she was housekeeper—she has said she was without money—my master has brought friends home to dinner—the prisoner did all the work—there was only one female kept—she used to take tea up to my master in bed for his breakfast in the morning—I have not noticed her staying longer than while he drank his tea—she staid till he finished, and then brought the empty cup down—I have heard her and her master have a few words—she has taken the book in, and I have heard her say he has not had money.

MR. JONES re-examined. The prisoner harbrought up a cup of tea to me—she has brought her book to me—I have never said to her, "D----n your eyes, I have no money; where am I to get it from?"—when I was away I allowed ten or twelve shillings a week, besides which there was bacon and cheese in the house for general use—I never knew that she pawned anything, or allowed it in anyway—I had a character with her from a school at Syden-tam, which induced me to take her—the plate was kept in a drawer in her room, in a basket which I gave her—she had a key of the drawer.

GUILTY . Aged 33.—Recommended to mercy by Prosecutor and Jury.—
Con
fined Eight Months.

2214.
MARIA TYLER
, stealing 1 watch, value 2l.; the goods of
Samuel Payne; having been before convicted.

PORTHENIA PAYNE . I am the wife of Samuel Payne, a warehouseman of St. George's, Southwark. The prisoner took an unfurnished room of me on 3rd Aug.—she said she had got a husband—I saw him the next morning, and her brother—the prisoner came about four o'clock in the afternoon of Thursday, and next day about half-past two o'clock I went up stairs, leaving the prisoner and my watch in the parlour—when I came down I met her in the passage—she went out—I went into the parlour, and in about ten minutes 1 missed the watch—this is it (produced)—a gold seal has been taken from it—I had one other lodger, who was up stairs at work.
JOHN-ROBERTS. I took this watch in pawn on the 4th Aug., from a young gave his name Henry Morrell—he has not been found—I gave him duplicate.
CAROLINE COLE . I am the wife of Henry Cole. I saw a policeman take
the prisoner in charge—her mother, who was with her, said her daughter had taken the watch through distress, and the prisoner touched her, not to say anything.
THOMAS PRITCHARD (police-sergeant, P 22). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's former conviction at Newington—(read—Convicted 24th, of May, 1847, confined six months)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 19.—
Confined Twelve Months.

2215.
MARY CARTER
, stealing 1 scarf, value 7s., and 1 handkerchief value 9d.; the goods of
James Fry, from his person; having been before convicted.

JAMES FRY . On Saturday evening, 26th Aug., I was going over Batter-sea-bridge—I was accosted by the prisoner—she requested me to accompany her over the bridge—we went over, and went into a public-house and had some gin—she then accompanied me to a lane leading to Battersea-fields—I had a scarf in my pocket, folded in a handkerchief—after I parted with the prisoner I missed it—I returned and saw her at an oyster-stall, with five or six men and women—I waited and saw her draw the scarf from under her shawl or from her pocket—I made a grasp at it—she swore at me and asked what I was at—I said that was my scarf and she had robbed me of it—she turned round and ran away to a crowd, where she remained some time—when the policeman came up I gave her in charge—the scarf has not been found.

Prisoner. Q. You said you did not blame me so much as the other young woman? A. No; I said I suspected the other young woman had got it—there was no other person with me when I lost it—I was not intoxicated.
JAMES SHUTTLEWORTH (policeman, V 144). I took the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. He said I had bis handkerchief in my hand, and it was only the corner of the shawl I have on now; I was wiping my five with it.

CHARLES CHINN (policeman, A 255). I produce a certiscate of of the pri
soner's former conviction—(read—Convicted Sept. 1847, confined six weeks)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 30.—
Confined Twelve Months.

2216.
ISABELLA SUTTON
, stealing 1 handkerchief, value 1s. 6d.; the goods of
Robert William Archbutt, having been before convicted.

ROBERT WILLIAM ARCHBUTT . I am a pawnbroker in Blackfriars'-road this handkerchief (produced) is mine, and has my private mark on it—I saw it safe on the 25th Aug., between five and six o'clock in the afternoon, and missed it about ten next morning, when the officer brought it to me—the pri
soner had come to my shop, and offered something to pawn—she gave me an address, which I did not think right, she left, and in about two minutes she came back—I am sure she is the person.

SAMUEL BARNETT . I am a pawnbroker in St. George's-circus, Blackfroars. On 26th Aug., a little after nine o'clock, the prisoner came to pawn this hand
kerchief—I discovered a mark on the corner, sent for an officer, and gave her charge with the handkerchief.

JOHN MASON (policeman, L 134). I took the prisoner and the handier
chief, she said she got it from a man, and she took me to a public-house—the man was not there—I then took her to the station.
Prisoner's Defence. A nan gave me the handkerchief.

WILLIAM PENNY (policeman, E 140). I produce a certificate of the pri
soner's
conviction at Clerkenwell—(read—Convicted Nov. 1847, confined four months)—the prisoner is the person.

GUILTY . Aged 30.
Confined Twelve Months.

2217.
CATHERINE CRAWLEY
, stealing 1 shawl, and other articles, value 2l. 11s. 9d., the goods of
Charles Hart, her master: also, 1 handker
chief, 3d.; the goods of
William Barker; and 1 handkerchief, 9d.; and one collar, 4d.; the goods of
James Waterman, her master: to all which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 29.—
Confined Six Months.

2218.
WILLIAM JOHNSON
, unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin.

SARAH SWIXDELL . I am the wife of James Swindell, a general-dealer in Wellington-street. On 14th Sept., the prisoner came for a quarter of an ounce of tobacco, and gave me a shilling—I gave him 11 1/4 d. change, and he left—I looked at the shilling, it was one of the Queen's reign—I tried to bend it—I then put it into the till—there were three other shillings there—an officer came in in a few minutes—I had not taken any other money—I then took the money from the till—there were four shillings altogether, one a Queen's, and the other three King's.

ANN DIXON . I assist Mr. Turner, a general-dealer, of Broad Wall. On 14th Sept., the prisoner came for half an ounce of tobacco—he gave me a shilling—I tried it with my teeth—it was hard, and I did not think it was bad—an officer came in, and I gave him the shilling.

THOMAS WEST (policeman, M 249). On 14th Sept., I was with Whit
lamb—I saw the prisoner in Friar-street with another man—we followed them, and saw the prisoner go into Mrs. Swindell's shop—after he came out, I went in, and received this shilling from Mrs. Swindell—I came out, and saw the prisoner again, in company with the same man—they went on to Broad Wall, and the prisoner left the other man, and went into Mr. Turner's—I went in as soon as I heard the money go on the counter, took the prisoner by the collar, and told him I wanted him for passing bad money—I saw Whitlamb take the shilling.
JOHN WHITLAMB (policeman, M 89). I took the shilling—the prisoner became violent—the other man got away.
CALEB EDWARD POWELL . I am inspector of coin to the Royal Mint—these shillings are both counterfeit.

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined Six Months.

2219.
WILLIAM WESSON
, stealing 1 sack, value 1s.; and 1 1/2 bushel of beans, value 3s.; the goods of
James Page, his master.

JAMES PAGE . I am a farmer at Merton. The prisoner was my carter—it was his duty to feed the horses—I went to his house, and found these beans—they are mine, and the sack also—he said it was his custom to take the horses food to his house—he had no business to do so, there is a proper bin in the stable for it.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. How far is his house from the stable? A. About fifty yards; I think I found these beans under the bed—they are inferior—he has been with me five or six years—he said he had taken them to feed his horses—he treated his horses well, and liked to see them fat—they work the better for it.
NOT GUILTY .

2220.
WILLIAM WESSON was again indicted
for stealing 1 bushel of wheat, in the chaff, value 7s.; the goods of
James Page, his master.

JAMES PAGE . I had some wheat, which ought to have been in my bars—this sack of wheat was found in the bin, in the stable—it is mine—the prisoner had no business to take it—I said to him, "Will, you have been robbing me"—he pleaded for mercy—he said before the Magistrate that he took it for his horses—I do not give wheat to horses; it would kill a horse, being new wheat.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you never know that wheat was very fattening to a horse? A. No; we always give wheat-chaff with the horses' food, but not wheat.
NOT GUILTY .

2221.
WILLIAM JONES
, stealing 7 sovereigns, 2 half-crowns, and 4 pence; the moneys of
Hannah Haines, in the dwelling-house of
John Redfern.

HANNAH HAINES . I am single, and live in Brunswick-court, in the parish of Christ Church, Surrey.
