I am thirty-four years old—I lived with the prisoner ten or eleven weeks, as his wife, and he agreed that we should go to Australia—I allowed him to sell my furniture, and we went together to Woolwich, to embark—about half an hour before we were to go, he came and told me the ship had started at four o'clock in the morning—I had got my furniture by being in service—the prisoner is nothing at all—he is twenty-two years old—my furniture is all gone—the prisoner gave it away; he did not make much of it—he had promised me marriage, but he said he had not got money enough—we did not stop all night at Woolwich; we came back to my lodging in the evening—I had seven sovereigns, five shillings, and some halfpence, wrapped up in my pocket—they were safe on the night of 22nd Aug.—I went to bed with the prisoner as usual—he got up about ten minutes after five o'clock next morning, and went out between five and six—I got up at seven, and after a while I found my pocket between the box and the wall, but my money was gone out of it—I had seen the money safe when I went to bed in the evening—there was no one in the room but me and my girl, who is ten years old—I am a widow—I went to look after the prisoner—I could not find him—after two days I found him at the Surrey Theatre—I went up to him, and asked him if he was not a pretty fellow—he said, "No, not at all "—I said, "How came you to take my money?"—he said he had not taken it.

THOMAS GARIORTH (policeman, L 151). I went with the prosecutrix, and took the prisoner—he said, "Me! I know nothing about it"—I found this watch on him—I asked him how long he had had it—he said he had had it a good bit, and he had bought it—he had a gold ring on his finger, and two new handkerchiefs, and he had on a new shirt—he said they were all his, and he bought them.

HANNAH HAINES
re-examined. The prisoner had none of these articles when he was with me; he was very destitute.

GEORGE TARR . I am a watch-maker. The prisoner bought this watch of me at Woolwich—I cannot say the day—he gave me 9s. and an old watch for it, and he gave me 2l. 15s., to take care of for him till the next morning.

Prisoner's Defence. I was living in Paddington; I went out one Sunday for some salt; I met the prosecutrix; she said she would give me some; we got talking; she said she was all alone, except a little girl of ten years old, and asked me to runic to tea with her. which I did, and we went out together;

from that time we kept company; she asked me to sleep with her, which I did; in about a fortnight we fell out, and I left her; she came after me in a week after, and we made it up, and lived together till last Saturday three weeks; we went to Woolwich, to go to Australia, but were too late for the ship; we came to town, and I took her to a friend of mine; on the Tuesday morning I got up at five o'clock, and went out to look for work; I had a few shillings, and got my watch out of pawn, and exchanged it for another; on Thursday I came to London, and was taken; she had given me money to buy a false certificate of marriage and a gold wedding-ring; she used to spend her money in waste; I am innocent of the robbery.

GUILTY . ** Aged 22.—
Transported for Ten Years.

2222.
HENRY RANDALL,
WILLIAM COBBETT , and
RICHARD RANDALL
, stealing 8lbs. weight of beef, 1 3/4 lb. of veal, and 1 1/4 lb. of mutton, value 5s. 6d.; the goods of
Mark Wade, the master of Henry Randall and Cohbett.
MARK WADE . I am a butcher, of Crown-street, Walworth. Henry Randall and Cobbett were in my service—the meat produced is mine.

SAMUEL WRIGHT (policeman, P 172). On 10th Sept. I was set to watch Mr. Wade's shop—about seven o'clock in the morning I saw Henry Randall and Cobbett go in—Richard Randall followed them—in two minutes Richard came out with a blue apron under his arm—he went to Turner-street—I stopped him, and asked what he had got—he said he bought the meat for 4d. a pound—I asked what it weighed—he said he could not tell—I asked what he gave for it—he said he had not paid for it—I took him to the station, and took the meat to his master—there was 8lbs. of beef, 1 3/4 lb. of veal, and some mutton.

EDWARD AUGUST (policeman, P 206). I saw the prisoners go into the shop—Richard Randall came out, and was followed by Wright—while he was gone Cobbett, came out with a white cloth and some mutton in it.
Richard Randall's Defence. The meat was given to me to take to a person.
Cobbett's Defence. I had paid 5s. for the meat.

MARK WADE
re-examined. Cobbitt had a right sell meat—the money that was there was marked—I had sent a woman to buy some meat with it—there was no other money there.

HENRY RANDALL—
GUILTY . Aged 20.

COBBETT—
GUILTY . Aged 26.

RICHARD RANDALL—
GUILTY . Aged 21.

2223.
EDGAR JOHN SARGEANT
, stealing 3 shirt-studs, value 4l.; the goods of
George Gilbert Nash, his master, to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 22.—
Confined Six Months.

2224.
WILLIAM BONE
, stealing 1 watch, value 2l.; the goods of
Henry Hunter; and
SAMUEL BONE
, feloniously receiving the same, he having been before convicted; to which

WILLIAM BONE pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Two Months.

SAMUEL BONE pleaded
GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Nine Months.

2225.
MARGARET KERR
, stealing 1 shawl and other articles, value 1l. 13s., the goods of
Edward Lemnel Cockerell , her master; to which she pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 18.—
Confined Six Months.

2226.
CATHERINE WOODBINE
, stealing 1 gown and other articles value 16s.; the goods of
Samuel Watkins Saunders, her master and
WILLIAM KING
, feloniously receiving the same; to which WOODBINE pleaded
GUILTY , and received a good character.—Aged 16.—
Confined Seven Days.

SAMUEL WATKINS SAUNDERS . I am an engineer, at Castle-street, St. Saviour's, Southwark. On 21st Aug. Woodbine came into my service—on the 28th she was sent out, and went away—next morning we missed a silver spoon and some other articles—these are them.

REBECCA KING . I am the mother of the prisoner King. On 29th Aug, he came and asked me whether I would allow a young woman to wash herself, who was a decent young woman, and had been turned out of doors—I said "Fetch her"—he and another youth came with Woodbine—she washed herself and went away—in about two hours she came and brought a bundle—she said she had these things from a coffee-shop—I went with her to the pawn-broker's, and she took the shawl off her back, and pawned it, and a spoon which she said she had found.
JAMES TALBOT . I am a pawnbroker. King brought this waistcoat to pawn—I detained him.
King's Defence. Woodbine gave me the duplicate—I took the waistcoat out, and went to pawn it—they stopped me.

KING—
NOT GUILTY .

2227.
WILLIAM WILSON
, stealing 1 table, value 3s., the goods of
Thomas Dice; having been before convicted.

THOMAS DICE . I am a broker, of Bedford-cottage, Clapham. On 29th Aug. I came home, and found the prisoner there—he told me he called re
specting a sofa I had—I told him there was a party about to buy it—he said it was a thing he should like very much, and he asked if I had any money paid on it—I said, "I have not, and unless we have a deposit paid on it we don't consider it sold "—he saw it, and said, "Well, I should like much to have it"—I said, "You shall have it "—he said, "I can't take it now; I will give you half-a-crown deposit, and fetch it away in the evening"—the price was 3s.—I went out about half-past seven o'clock, and returned at half-past ten, and found the sofa was gone and a table also—I had not sold him the table, or authorised him to have it.
Cross-examined by MR. PAYNE. Q. You went to his lodging, and found him and the table? A. Yes; I had not been drinking—I swear positively the prisoner bought the sofa, and not the table.
ELIZABETH DICE . I was present when the sofa was bought—there was no table bought.

ELIZABETH DICE , the younger. About eight o'clock the prisoner came and asked if my father or mother were at home—I said, "No "—he said he came for the sofa—I told him I would not open the gate to let him out till my father came home—he said he could not wait humbugging for my father, he had got his own business to attend to—he told my little brother to open the back-gate—he took the sofa out—he said he had paid for the table, and took it.
Cross-examined. Q. He paid you 6d. for the sofa? A. Yes.
JOHN COLTMAN (policeman, V 296). I went to the prisoner's lodging, and found the table and the sofa—he said he had bought them.

JOHN MAY (policeman, V 281). I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction—(read—Convicted Feb., 1846, and confined six months)—he is the man—he has been in custody since that for embezzlement.

GUILTY . Aged 23.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2228.
JAMES MAGGS
, stealing 37lbs. weight of lead, value 5s.; the goods of
James Courthorp Peache and another, fixed to a building; having been before convicted.

CHARLES BENNETT . On 25th Aug. I lived at 1, Oxford-place, Lambeth. A little before twelve at night I heard a noise on the roof, and shortly after
wards saw the prisoner in custody—the lead had been repaired two days before—I found 25lbs. of lead severed from the roof—I compared it with the lead on the house—it corresponded.

JOHN WEBB . I am a shoemaker, at 15, Barrett's-buildings. On 25th Aug., a little before twelve o'clock at night, I was with a policeman near the house in question, and saw the prisoner go in at his own window—he came I round the copeing in a direction from 1, Oxford-place—in a few minutes I saw him brought out by the policeman.

Crost-examined by MR. CARTER.Q. Where did the prisoner live? A. At No. 17—No. 16 and 17 are kept by one person—I was in a beer-house that night, and saw the prisoner on the roof—it was a darkish night—the house was three stories high, and the window was eighteen or nineteen feet from where I stood—I could not see the face of the person on the roof—I saw he bad a large fur cap on, which the prisoner usually wears—I had seen him twenty times, and the cap too—I know him very well.

JOSEPH RACKSTRAW (policeman, L 170). I was on duty, and saw the prisoner on the roof of 1, Oxford-place, and 17, Barrett's-buildings—they join together—they are corner houses—the prisoner came from the corner of Oxford-place, and went into 17, Barrett's-buildings.
Cross-examined. Q. How low is this house? A. I suppose the window be got in at was about fifteen feet high—I suppose a hundred persons were there.

JOHN OULD (policeman, L 87). About a quarter to twelve o'clock that night I went to Oxford-place with Bennett—I saw a man doing something on the top of 1, Oxford-place—I went into 17, Barrett's-buildings—I found the prisoner standing by the fire-place, with a large hairy cap on his head—I took him, and told him he must go with me for being outside the next house—he said he had been to bed, and had just got up.
THOMAS STROUD (policeman, L 174). I found the lead on the top of No. 17, about a yard and a half from the window—five pieces were taken from No. 1, and two from No. 5.
Cross-examined. Q. Had you been on the roof? A. No—here is the mark of a knife on the lead—No 5 is thirty or forty yards from No. 1—you can go right along the whole row.
THOMAS FILES . I am agent to James Courthorp Peache and Mr. Roper—they are the joint owners of No. 1, Oxford-place.
Cross-examined. Q. Are they partners? A. No; joint freeholders of the property—they built the house and I receive the rents, and pay Mr. Roper half and Mr. Peache half,
JOHN PIKE . I produce a certificate of the prisoner's conviction at Bath—(read, "Convicted April, 1847, confined three months")—I was present—he is the man.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you know his character before that? A. He had a good character given him by two of the Jurors.

GUILTY . Aged 32.—
Transported for Seven Years.

2229.
HENRY PLACEY
, stealing 6lbs. weight of sausages, value 5s. of, the goods of
William Parker, his master; and
WILLIAM SIMMONS
felo
niously receiving the same.

WILLIAM PARKER . I am a sausage-maker, at High-street, Southwark—Placey was in my employ. On 26th Aug. I delivered him about 1 1/2 cwt. of meat, some beef, and some pork, to chop it, season it, and bring it into the shop in the shape of sausages—I delivered him the last quantity about one o'clock, and between two and three he was brought to me by the policeman arid a basket, containing about six pounds of pork sausages—I have no doubt they were mine by the style of them.
Cross-examined by MR. BALLANTINE Q. Was the meat cut? A. Yes—my sausages have a different look to most sausages.

WILLIAM GRIST (policeman, M 223). On 26th Aug., about half-past two o'clock, I saw Placey come out of the shop—he looked rather bulky in front—he went into the Black Horse and Crown, into the private box, in front of the bar—Simmons was there, with an empty basket and a cloth in it—in about seven minutes Placey came out and went to a watering-place—he had two jugs of beer in his hand—he set them on the ground, and appeared to be undoing his trowsers—Simmons came out with the basket, and put it towards Placey, while he was in the watering-place—I saw a number of sausages turned into the basket—Simmons covered the cloth over them and was going away—I took Placey, and found on him 5l. 12s.

THOMAS SWAINE (policeman, M 106). I saw Placey go to the public-house, come out, and go to the watering-place, and Simmons after him—he turned some sausages into this basket—I took him with the basket as he was going away—I asked what he had got—he said he had nothing—I found these sausages in the basket.
(The prisoners received good characters.)

PLACEY—
GUILTY . Aged 22.

SIMMONS—
GUILTY . Aged 23.

p.hi:
Recommended to mercy by the Jury.—
Confined Three Months.

div1.p:
2230.
ANN DAY
, stealing 1 watch, value 5l.; the goods of
John Palmer, from his person.

JOHN PALMER . I am a gentleman, and live at Walworth. On 7th Sept., about twelve o'clock at night, I was taking a little walk—I had had sundry glasses of grog—I called a cab in Holborn—I was accompanied by two females, who asked for a ride—the prisoner was one—we rode to the Elephant and Castle, and there had three or four glasses of brandy-and-water—we were then walking along the Walworth-road—I missed a small Geneva watch—I accused them—they both denied it—they were taken to the station—this is my watch.

Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. You were very drunk? A. I was a little fresh—I bad been to a sporting-house, Spring's, in Holborn—I had my watch when I left the cab—I had a friend with me—he left me, and then I had the two ladies—I had not been in any house, but merely to have some brandy-and-water, I would not like to swear it positively—one of the women took my watch—next morning I was not labouring under the effects of drink to any effect—I knew what I said before the Magistrate.
JOHN BAKER (policeman). I found the prisoner and prosecutor together about three o'clock in the morning—the prisoner and the other woman were searched, but nothing was found.

THOMAS LOCKYER (policeman, F 135). On the following morning I put a wire down the water-closet at the station, and got this watch up—the pri
soner, the other woman, and one more were in that cell.
Cross-examined. Q. How long afterwards did you find it? A. It might be an hour—the prosecutor said the other girl was not with him when the prisoner took it.
NOT GUILTY .

2231.
JAMES MORRIS
, stealing 1l. 6d.; the moneys of
James Shaw, his master; to which he pleaded

GUILTY . Aged 14.—
Confined Fourteen Days.

2232.
THOMAS JONES
, stealing 1 handkerchief, value 2s. 6d.; the goods of
John Barton, from his person.

JOHN BARTON . I live in Westminster-road, and am an auctioneer. On 8th Sept. I was in Oakley-street, Westminster-road—I felt an attack on my pocket—I turned and saw a person turn up a street, who I have no doubt was the prisoner, by his brown coat which he wore—I went into the main street—there was a crowd with some music—I stopped for a moment, and found a second attack on my pocket—I turned and saw the prisoner dose to me—he went away, and I pursued him—he was stopped, and I went up—I put my band into his pocket, and found a handkerchief—he said, "That is not your handkerchief," and I think he said, "That is cotton"—mine was a silk handkerchief.

WILLIAM COCKERELL (policeman, L 108). I heard a cry of "Stop thief!"—I saw the prisoner stopped opposite Allen-street—I went up, and Mr. Barton accused him of stealing his handkerchief—the prisoner said, "I have not got it; yours was a silk one"—he took a cotton handkerchief out of his pocket, and said, "That is not yours; that is a cotton one."

JOHN BARTON
re-examined. I saw nobody with the prisoner—there might have been, as there was a crowd of people—he was close behind me, and nobody else near me.

Prisoner. He said, "That lad stole my silk handkerchief;" that was why I said mine was cotton. Witness. I did not say anything about a silk hand
kerchief.
NOT GUILTY .

2233.
CHARLES REBURN
, feloniously and knowingly uttering a forged order for the payment of 2l. 15s., with intent to defraud
Isaac Rose.

JOHN TIMOTHY . I am an upholsterer, of Tooley-street. On 22nd Aug. I was in a public-house, about eleven o'clock in the morning—I saw the pri
soner, with a pen and ink in his hand—he stated he was going to Quebec, as steward in a ship, and that he had an advance-note that he wanted to get cashed, and he would give any one 6s. if they would tell him where he could get it cashed—he bought a mattress and palliasse of me for 6s.—I then took him to Mr. Rose.
Cross-examined by MR. CHARNOCK. Q. How came you to take him to Mr. Rose? A. He said he wanted some things, and he wanted his note cashed—he said he would pay me when he got it cashed.

ISAAC ROSE . I am a clothier in Tooley-street. On 22nd Aug. the pri
soner came to my shop—he produced this note and said he wished it cashed he said he was steward of the Wallace barque, going to Quebec—he said

he would take part in clothes—he looked out clothes to the amount of 2l. 1s. 6d., and I gave him 13s. 6d.—it was raining at the time, and he took a cap and an umbrella, and the other things were to be sent to the Docks—they were sent and they came back, there was no such vessel—the prisoner wrote the name of Charles Reed on the back of the order—when these orders are passed it is customary for the person to write his own name on them.

JOHN WILLIAM BROWN . I am clerk to Messrs. Steinback and Son, they are brokers to the ship Wallace, Captain Robert Morton—she sailed on the 19th Aug.—I have a list of the seaman, returned to us by the captain from the Downs—we chartered the vessel—the name of Reed or Reburn does not appear in this list—we should not pay any money on this paper—I do not know Mr. Robert Forbes—I have not made inquiry for him.

Cross-examined. Q. May there not be another ship called Wallace? A. There may, I believe there are many—I dare say there are many Mortons—men sometimes join the ship at Gravesend after it is cleared out—this paper is brought up by the pilot who leaves the ship in the Downs—if a man joins the ship after the pilot leaves, we should not have the account in this paper, but if the man has an advance-note we should have an account from the cap
tain.
MR. ROBINSON. Q. When did the ship sail? A. She cleared out at the Customs on 19th Aug., and went down to Gravesend the same day.

JOSEPH DATE . I am a clerk in the Register Office for Seamen. I pro
duce the official list of the crew on board the Wallace of Glasgow, which sailed for Quebec—this list is deposited by the captain, and signed by him on the completion of his crew—this is signed just before the vessel goes—it is made evidence by the Act of Parliament—the name of Reid or Reburn is not here—there may be many vessels named Wallace, but they would not agree with this in the tonnage, the day of sailing, and the captain's name—I have made inquiries respecting these facts from public books, and from those in
quiries I can undertake to say that there was no other Wallace, Captain Mor
ton, sailed for Quebec on that day—this note bears the name of Reburn—I had an official counterpart of the same—it bears a number which is supposed to be the number of the prisoner's register-ticket—it is 74360—I have ascertained that the name of the person to whom No. 74360 is applicable, is Thorns Lacey.

EVAN-JONES (policeman, M 250). I took the prisoner—I told him the charge—he said nothing then—he afterwards said we ought to take the other man he received that note from—I took from him this seaman's ticket, with the name of Reburn on it—I read the name of Charles Reburn—he said, "That is my name; that is my ticket."

GUILTY . Aged 20.—
Confined One Year.
(There were three other charges against the prisoner.)

2234.
WILLIAM JONES
, feloniously cutting and wounding
Robert Sut
ton on his head, with intent to do him some grievous bodily harm.

ROBERT SUTTON . I work on the parish roads. I know the prisoner—he works on the turnpike-trust, and in the fields in the evening—on 5th Sept., I was in the Crown and Anchor, at Wandsworth—the prisoner was there—he addressed a great many observations to me, and wanted to quarrel with me—I did not say much to him—he went out and I followed him—he began to abuse me again, and called me a parish robber—I asked what he meant by

that and he crossed the road, picked up a scraper, struck me with it on the forehead, and knocked me down with it—he left me senseless, and went away—I bad never given him any offence—I was smothered in blood when I got up—I staggered up the road after him—a yonng man had taken him, and I gave charge of him—I was taken to the doctor's about twelve o'clock.

Cross-examined by MR. HORRY. Q. Your arm is bound up? A. That is the effect of the wound on the head—it is not an old complaint—my arm is drawn up and inflamed—I went to the public-house about half-past ten o'clock—the prisoner and others were there—I had a pint of beer, and the prisoner drank with me—this happened after the house was closed—I did not say anything about his having taken a job from me—there was no dispute about a hay-making job—Shillito did not say to me, "Go on, Bob "—he did not say, "Well done;" nothing of the sort passed—I did not strike or push the prisoner—he had not the scraper in his hand—he crossed the road and picked it up.

JOHN SHILLITO . I am a tailor. I was at the Crown and Anchor on 5th Sept., between ten and eleven o'clock—I saw the prosecutor and the prisoner in the tap-room—they were laughing, joking, and drinking together—there was no foul language while I was there, till they came out—Jones came out first, and Sutton after him—Jones called Sutton a parish-bred b----r—Sutton. went up to him, and asked him if he called himself a man to call him that—Jones then went and took the scraper, and knocked him down with it—Jones ran away, and I ran and overtook him—Sutton was not at all offensive to Jones while I was there.

Cross-examined. Q. How long were you in the public-house? A. I went about a quarter before eleven o'clock—the prisoner was not at all tipsy—Sutton was not angry; he took all in good part—they were both in the house when I went in—they did nothing but chaff one another inside—there was no violence till they got outside.

GEORGE TETCHNER . I was inside the public-house—I heard the prose
cutor and the prisoner laughing and joking about their situations—the prisoner called Sutton a hay-maker—I went out first—I saw them come out—Jones called Sutton a parish-bred b—r, and Sutton went and asked him if he called himself a man—Jones went to the side of the road, got the scraper, struck him on the head, and knocked him down—Jones threw down the scraper and ran away—some one picked it up and gave it to me—I gave it to the officer.
JOHN DENDY (policeman, V 93). I took the prisoner, and produce the scraper, which was given me by Tetchner.
Cross-examined. Q. The prisoner said it was an accident, that he did not do it wilfully? A. Yes.

JOHN PEARCE . I am a surgeon, of Larkhall-lane. On the night of 5th Sept. Sutton was brought to me, suffering from a severe contused wound, close on the skull, as deep as it could go—I saw him the next day—there was a great deal of constitutional disturbance, which might have arisen from an old wound on the hand—it might have been the wound, or it might have been from drink—it might have happened without the wound—I saw him on we Thursday following—he was very ill, and suffering a great deal from the head—I was obliged to bleed him—this wound was not dangerous, because there was no fracture—his arm is bound up from a constitutional disturbance he may be subject to fits from the effects of this wound.
Cross-examined. Q. If a blow had been struck with this instrument, would it not have broken the skull? A. If it had struck him with the centre of we instrument.

GUILTY . Aged 42.—
Confined One Year.

2235.
CHARLES SMITH WESTON
, stealing 1 pair of boots, and other articles, value 1l. 9s. 6d.; the goods of
Frederick William Zeels.

FREDERICK WILLIAM ZEELS (through an interpreter). On 5th Sept, I had a bag on board my vessel, containing these articles—I saw the prisoner going from my vessel with the bag—some of my things have been found—these are them.
Prisoner. I cannot speak his language; he gave me these things in my hand. Witness. No, I did not.

ELLEN BOCOTT . I live at Shadwell. On Wednesday, 6th Sept., the prisoner came to me and brought this blanket and boots, about seven o'clock—the policeman came and had them—he brought three bags, and some other things to me, but he took them out again.

WILLIAM CHARLES POTTER (policeman, K 212). I took the prisoner, and told him what for—he said he knew nothing about it, but at the station it said he had sold the things—I got these things from Bocott.

GUILTY . *—
Confined One Year.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY, OCTOBER 23RD.
